dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail-clad HORSEMEN gallop headlong through the dark, bent low over their saddles. A bestial scream is heard, and suddenly a saddle is empty, the rider sprawled face down a pool of blood. At the head of the band, COLWYN, a boy of twenty-two, rai his shield to ward off an unseen assailant. We hear a horrendous tearing sound, and Colwyn's father, TUROLD, riding beside him, looks over at the boy. Colwyn is unhar - but his shield is deeply gouged, as if by a huge claw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUARD sees the band of warriors emerge from the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Open the gate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warriors gallop toward the main gate of the castle. Though their arms and armor are reminiscent of the Middle Ages on Earth, this is not Earth ...

dialogues.speaker: TWIN SUNRISE
dialogues.text: Behind the riders, TWO SUNS rise above the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turold and Colwyn lead their men through the gate and dismount. Waiting for them are LORD ROWAN, a man of Turol age, and an elderly COUNCILOR. Rowan notices the gouges i Colwyn's shield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Turold) You were attacked in the forest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We lost five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were lucky. I lost thirty there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turold and Rowan walk down the corridor, followed by Colw and the Councilor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to reach Ynyr, the old one. I led a hundred men to his place in Granite Needle, but it was surrounded. The Dark Ones guard it by night and by day they call out the Slayers. Ynyr cannot get out and no one can get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many did you lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty at the needle, another thirty in the forest. Only ten of us made it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will have to try again. His knowledge is great. Without it, we cannot hope to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN is propped up in bed, eyes closed, head tilted back. Her crown, a jeweled tiara, rests in her lap. She i attended by two GIRLS-IN-WAITING, one of whom sponges her forehead with a damp cloth. The Queen opens her eyes as t elderly Councilor enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Turold and his son, my lady. The Queen hands her tiara to one of the girls-in-waiting, who places it on her head. Then she nods, and the Council admits Turold and Colwyn, followed by Rowan. The three kneel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has turned out well. Turold stands and looks down at Colwyn with an affectiona smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Middling well. Colwyn stands and we see that he is several inches taller than his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though a touch too tall for my taste. Colwyn smiles somewhat sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colwyn) My daughter is in the north tower. Go to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) In my armor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she's to marry a warrior, she'd best get used to it. Colwyn bows his head and leaves. The three men approach t Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What news from our friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barak is still strong in the north, and Tendo holds the high passes. But the great desert forts have fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freylag's stronghold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been taken, Freylag and all his people slaughtered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only a few weeks and already half our strong places have fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attacks are unceasing: by night, the Dark Ones; by day, those of our people who have sold themselves to them, those traitors who are called the Slayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the way of all invaders. Those they would conquer they divide, buying allies with promises of land and power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will hold. Their power is not unlimited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two mounted SLAYERS ride along the road. Their horses and armor are black, as are their cylindrical, flat-topped helmets, pierced with a T-slot for vision. Their weapons long-swords and maces. Two more Slayers ride out of the forest and join the blac column. At a road up ahead wait three more, who swing in behind the column as it passes. Forest noises die at the Slayers' approach; the only soun we hear are the clink of metal and the heavy thud of the horses' hooves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn mounts a narrow, circular staircase toward a woode door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LYSSA, the Queen's seventeen-year-old daughter, stares across the circular room at the wooden door, listening to Colwyn's approaching footsteps. The door swings open and Colwyn enters. They stare at eac other for several moments: Colwyn, dusty and disheveled i his armor, Lyssa freshly scrubbed and glowing in a diaphanous gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) I'm Colwyn. Lyssa nods, noncommittal. They start to circle the room, eyes fixed on each other, like a pair of nervous cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (plaintive) Are you Lyssa? She gives him another noncommittal nod. They resume their tentative circling. Suddenly, Lyssa turns away, leaning on the sill of a narr window. Her shoulders begin to heave, as if she's sobbing Colwyn is in agony; he rushes across the room to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what arrangements were made by our parents. You don't have to go through with it! Lyssa continues to heave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't force you. I won't let them! Lyssa turns around, and Colwyn sees that she's not sobbin but laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to control her laughter) I'm sorry. I couldn't help it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking considerable umbrage) I don't have to go through with it either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still laughing, touches his arm) You don't understand. I'm just so relieved. I was sure you'd turn out to be short and fat and gimpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. That. (begins to chuckle) I know what you mean. (sits down on a bench) I had nightmares all week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits down beside him) Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night was the worst. I dreamt you had one leg shorter than the other, and walked like a penguin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine was worse: I dreamt you picked your nose in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really not bad looking. Almost handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might be handsome. I can't tell through all that grime. Besides, you reek of sweat and horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pompously) If you're going to marry a warrior, you'd best get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no intention of getting used to it. She goes over to a small cistern and fills a wooden bucke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take off your clothes. I'm going to scrub you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're almost married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not married yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then you can go up to the parapet and I'll hand the buckets up to you. Colwyn looks at the stone stairs leading to the top of th tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to? (looks at Lyssa, sighs) I have to. He starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of mounted Slayers waits at the crossing for another column to reach the intersection. The first colum falls in beside the second as it passes, forming a double column. Farther down the road waits LORD MODRED, a Slayer like th others, but distinguished by the leopard embroidered on h chest and by his lance, which bears a pennon affixed to i head: ermine, a leopard courant sable. As the double colu reaches him, he wheels and leads them down the road, lanc upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turold and Rowan at the Queen's bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Rowan is one of Lyssa's godfathers. He will defend her in the ceremony. I wish that Lord Modred were here. He is a godfather of her own blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modred has treated with the Dark Ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modred! Impossible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads a group of Slayers, under the leopard banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some, the lure of power is stronger than the ties of blood. No matter. I had hoped to have the wedding next spring, Lord Turold, with all the nobles of the kingdom in attendance. But Fate and this war have ordained otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is important to assure the succession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The Queen smiles and beckons Turold closer. He kneels bes the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will tell you something you did not know, Turold. Had it been my choice, all those years ago, I would have chosen you for my king. But my parents chose otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew! You are a rude bumpkin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) That I am, my lady. Turold looks out the window at the North Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, it seems, so is my son.

dialogues.speaker: NORTH TOWER
dialogues.text: Angle from the Queen's bedroom window. A waist-high wall conceals the bottom half of a naked Colwyn, who stands at the tower, hugging himself in the brisk wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn hears Lyssa mounting the stairs and moves to the doorway, reaching around to take the bucket from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Lyssa pushes past him) Just hand me the bucket! What are you doing! He backs away, covering himself with his hands. Lyssa advances on him; tucked in her belt, like a sword, is a long-handled bath brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't trust you to wash behind your ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind my ears! Go away! The Queen and Turold watch the unfolding drama from their window vantage point: a great tongue of water leaps acros the tower as Lyssa heaves the bucketful at Colwyn. Drippi wet, he retreats, but is soon cornered and attacked witho quarter, Lyssa wielding brush and soap with gleeful enthusiasm. At one point, Colwyn squirms free and, with h head completely enveloped in lather, tries to flee. But since he can't see, he soon fetches up against a wall, an Lyssa continues her scrubbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl of some spirit, your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A match for your son, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes his hand) They will have the life that you and I might have had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrapped in a long blue cape, a scrubbed and scowling Colw stands with arms folded across his chest. Lyssa is combin his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps back) There. Now you look like someone I might want to marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surly growl) Maybe you'd better look around for another candidate. I don't think my skin is tough enough to survive a lifetime of you and your brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to look around. I've found the husband I want. You can kiss me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, but I can wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. She bestows a class-A smack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait either. They close in a passionate kiss, and begin caressing each other. We see Turold standing in the doorway, watching th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll both wait. At least for five hours. The wedding is at three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acting offended) It was a platonic kiss, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it was. Turold snorts down a laugh. Colwyn and Lyssa begin to giggle. Then all three break into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The occupants of the castle - servants, soldiers, minor nobles, and retainers - stand in two parallel lines, form an aisle. Turold and Rowan, on horseback, face each other at opposi ends of the aisle. Midway between them stand Colwyn and Lyssa, side by side, Colwyn facing Rowan, Lyssa facing Turold. The two fathers are not armored, but they hold longswords balanced across their pommels. Colwyn glances up toward the Queen's balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen lies on a couch, attended by her two girls-in- waiting. She answers Colwyn's look with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts to Rowan) I am Colwyn, son of Turold, of the eagle's blood, and I am come to take your daughter from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) You shall not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts to Turold) I am Lyssa, daughter of the Queen, of the leopard's blood, and I am come to take your son from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) You shall not! The two men spur their horses toward the wedding couple, stand perfectly still as the horses thunder down on them. Turold and Rowan swing their swords directly above the he of the young couple, the blades striking with a clang. Th they wheel their horses to a stop. Colwyn and Lyssa, almo obscured by the whirling dust, have not moved a muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it be done then. He hurls his sword at the ground beside the wedding coupl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is done. He hurls his sword, which sticks in the ground beside Turold's, crossing it. A cheer goes up from the spectator and the guards on the walls. As Colwyn and Lyssa kiss, a crossbow bolt strikes one of guards, who topples thirty feet to the courtyard below. Slayers appear around the walls, leaping over the parapet and attacking the guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Slayers! To arms! Men and women arm themselves as Slayers descend the walls They mount a fierce counterattack against the Slayers, wo fighting beside their men, Lyssa fighting beside Colwyn. But suddenly the main gate is rammed open and a dozen Slayers on horseback, led by Modred, attack the defenders from the rear. In the melee, Colwynn and Lyssa are separated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen and her girls hear Slayers forcing the door to bedroom within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me up. I will die on my feet. The two girls help the Queen to stand. She faces the door defiantly as it bursts open. A Slayer steps into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will not die alone. She hurls a knife, which pierces the Slayer's throat. But even as he falls, three more Slayers enter the room and advance on the three women, who stare back defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn sees that his father is being pressed by several Slayers and hacks his way to his side. They dispatch thei assailants, then Colwyn looks through the courtyard for Lyssa, who has just run a Slayer through with her short sword, when she is felled from behind by Modred's mailed fist. He picks her up and lays her across his saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have Lyssa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't reach her! (opens a door in the wall) Through the door. (as Colwyn hesitates) Quickly! They go through the door, and are followed shortly by two Slayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn and Turold back down the dark corridor, fighting t two Slayers. They kill the Slayers but, in the exchange, Turold is badly wounded. He leans against the wall, holdi himself erect by force of will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passage. Open it. Colwyn pressed one of the rough-hewn stones and a door swings open in the wall: A staircase leads to an undergro passage. He moves to help his father through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) You will go alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't leave you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will do as I tell you. You will try to reach Ynyr, the old one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must follow the Slayers. They've taken Lyssa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) You will not follow the Slayers, you will obey my command! (softer) You have no chance alone, boy. You must try to break through to Ynyr. He has great knowledge. Only with his help can you save Lyssa. They hear footsteps in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go now. (as Colwyn hesitates) Go! I command you! As Colwyn enters the passage and begins swinging the heav door shut, Modred appears, advancing on Turold with drawn sword. Turold places himself in front of the door, but he weak from his wound and goes down under Modred's first bl Modred thrusts his sword into the crack of the door, preventing it from closing. Turold, slumped against the wall, looks up at him with pleading eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spare him, Modred. Have you never loved anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) If I spare him, they will kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is your godson now. He and Lyssa were married. Modred stares at him for some moments, then withdraws his sword, allowing the door to close. Turold flashes a look gratitude, then dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The castle is in flames, the occupants slain. The Slayers, mounted, wait in a double column for Modred' command. Lyssa sits on a horse in the middle of the colum her hands tied behind her. Modred approaches her with a s canteen of water, which she refuses by averting her face. steps back and signals the column, which trots out throug the main gate. As Modred mounts his horse to follow the column, the twin suns dip below the horizon. Modred rides through the main gate, disappearing in the shadows. We hear an inhuman scream, amplified by the stone walls of the gate. Modred's riderless horse emerges from the other side of t gate. A new angle shows Modred lying on the stone floor beneath the gate tower, his chest raked by deep gouges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn stands beside the exit of the underground passage, tears running down his cheeks as he stares at the burning castle in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forest ends abruptly, some distance from the edge of steep cliff. A natural stone bridge arches from the cliff the Granite Needle, a cylindrical formation that rises fr the floor of the valley below. Colwyn stands at the edge of the forest, looking out at a group of Slayers posted near the stone bridge. Nearby are pair of black tents housing more Slayers. He hears a noise and turns to see a Slayer behind him, drawing his sword. As the Slayer rushes, Colwyn hurls his knife at the T-slot in the Slayer's cylindrical helmet, striking him between the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn, wearing the dead Slayer's helmet and armor, approaches the group near the stone bridge. The bridge le to an opening in the side of the Needle, which gives acce to a passage which extends some ten feet into the Needle before it takes a right-angle turn. On the floor of the passage are heaped the bodies of half dozen Slayers; though Ynyr may not be able to get out, he clearly capable of preventing anyone from getting in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man must sleep sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sometime. But when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'd like to stroll across the bridge and find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go right ahead, brother, and let the old man put you to sleep forever ... (nods toward bodies) ... along with them. The Slayers laugh, but fall silent as Colwyn draws his sw and starts across the bridge. He moves across the bridge into the passageway, stepping over bodies as he nears the right-angle turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ynyr stares down the passage toward the right-angle turn. his hand, held out before him, is a silver glaive, a cros shaped weapon with four equal blades. When Colwyn rounds the corner into view, the glaive leaps from the old man's hand and spins down the passageway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling off his helmet) I am Colwyn, son of Turold! The glaive stops in midair, inches from Colwyn's throat. Realizing they've been tricked, two Slayers start across bridge to attack Colwyn. But the old man projects his gla past the boy, where it hangs in midair, spinning and glowing. The Slayers retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no way out. He will die there with the old man. In the cave, Colwyn stands in front of Ynyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White Castle has fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the Queen live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new Queen lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turold's son was to marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were married. Then she was taken by the Slayers. You must help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lived in this place, like my fathers before me, guarding the old knowledge. I knew, when I had no son, that the Great War would come in my time, and that I would be the one to pass on the old knowledge to a new king. Come. Colwyn glances toward the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is night. The Slayers have gone to their tents and the bridge is guarded by Dark Ones. They will not cross, for they have no power in this place. Colwyn follows Ynyr through a passageway to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn and Ynyr sit beside a fire in a triangular pit in floor. Colwyn has shed the Slayer's armor, and Ynyr holds black onyx box in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the first time the Dark Ones have attacked our world. They came once before, a thousand years ago. A young king and queen, with extraordinary powers, were given to us then, to lead the struggle. My fore-father was their Councilor, as I will be yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no extraordinary powers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your powers are greater than you know. (indicates his glaive) Have you ever seen one of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the old books. It's called a glaive. Ynyr opens the onyx box to reveal a golden glaive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This belonged to the young king who fought the Dark Ones a thousand years ago. Now it is yours. Colwyn picks up the glaive, turns it in his hands, the blades flashing in the firelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two or three days' practice, you'll be able to use it as well as I can. Then we'll have a chance of fighting our way out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two or three days! While Lyssa is in their hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at the fire) But there is another entrance to this place. Ynyr follows Colwyn's gaze and sees that he's judging fro the movement of the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it opens onto the sheer wall of the Needle. There's no way down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have rope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am too old to climb down a rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn inserts his glaive in a crack beside the opening, then ties a rope to the glaive and climbs down the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn reaches the ground and signals Ynyr, who unties th rope from the glaive and secures it around his waist. The he lowers the rope over the glaive, which allows Colwyn t lower him down the side of the Needle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Dark One watches them from the top of the cliff, its re eyes peering over the edge. The thing moves quickly down rock face, with only an occasional scrape or flash of cla to mark its descent. At the bottom of the cliff, the red eyes appear above a r - only a few yards from Colwyn. But before it can attack, trident flashes through the air and strikes the thing squ in the face, the outer prongs of the weapon piercing the eyes. We hear a death grunt, then the sound of a body falling. Colwyn turns, but sees nothing. He lowers Ynyr to the gro and they set off across the valley floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The golden glaive stands upright on Colwyn's outstretched palm. Ynyr kneels beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Focus on the glaive. Colwyn tenses with concentration. The glaive begins to sp at first slowly, then faster and faster until it's a gold blur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reach out with your mind. Reach out to Lyssa. Colwyn furrows his brow in concentration.

dialogues.speaker: COLWYN'S TELEPATHIC SEARCH
dialogues.text: Through a translucent image of Lyssa we see stretches of terrain moving past: bizarre forests and valleys, gargoyl mountains, rainbow lakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweating) There is nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reach out farther. Call to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa ... Lyssa ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG SHOT SHOWS only a series of jagged peaks, but as w MOVE IN, we SEE the outlines of a gigantic fortress, designed to blend into the mountains. Lyssa walks along the parapets of the fortress, a cold wi whipping at her light garments. The occasional glint of talon or beak, the quick flash of a red eye, tell us that she is closely watched and guarded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly at first, then louder) Lyssa ... Lyssa ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they harmed you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They watch me closely, but they haven't harmed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colwyn) Where? We must know where she is. Colwyn's face is bathed in sweat, his hand clenched tight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa. Where are they keeping you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a great fortress in the mountains. Wait. Something's happening. As the twin suns edge above the horizon, the fortress fad and disappears. The whistle of the wind changes to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... tropical bird sounds as the Fortress appears in the midst of the jungle, its walls covered with liana vines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's changed. Now the fortress is in the jungle. Colwyn's body is shaking from the strain of maintaining contact. Ynyr grips his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough, boy. But Colwyn continues to concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough! Ynyr slaps him sharply, knocking him backward. The boy li exhausted, breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must break when the strain becomes too great, or you will harm yourself. And you must concentrate your powers for when they are needed most. What did she answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was in a great fortress, first in the mountains, then in the jungle. How is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the Fortress of Krull. I know it only from the stories of wars on other worlds. They did not use it on our world in the first great war, for it costs them enormous power. This time they mean to conquer, at all costs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fortress moves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Each dawn it rises in a different land: sometimes in the mountains, sometimes in the jungle, sometimes the desert, sometimes the sea. Never in the same place twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then even if Lyssa tells us where she is, we'll never be able to reach her, for they will never allow the Fortress to rise near us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They occupy the Fortress, but they cannot control its movement. It is moved by Fate. And, sooner or later, Fate will place it near us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we must be ready. Five leagues from here is the Eastern Tower. I know the Barons who hold it. Good men, and brave. They will help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have not slept in two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor will I, till my bride is beside me. They set off through the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Colwyn. Colwyn. She hears the scrape of a taloned foot behind her and hurries along the parapet. She stops and looks down at a small clearing in the jungle, outside the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fawn grazes in the clearing, unaware of a white leopard poised on a branch above it. As the leopard is about to pounce, it glances up and sees Lyssa staring down from th Fortress wall. As if in answer to her summons, it jumps t the ground and heads for the wall. The leopard leaps onto the walkway in front of Lyssa, the moves obediently to her side. They set off down the walkw together. Suddenly the leopard whirls and roars as it hears the scr of a taloned foot behind. But other Dark Ones are in fron of them. Lyssa is forced to descend a stone staircase. Th leopard, acting as rear guard, roars its defiance as it backs down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn and Ynyr are about to cross the tiny stream, when suddenly a small white cloud materializes above the water bulging and gyrating, affording brief glimpses of feet an hands, as if a small man were trying to escape. As Colwyn jumps back, drawing his sword, the cloud vanishes with a and the small man, ERGO, is plopped on his seat in the wa (which is only a few inches deep).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help! Help! I'm drowning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it. The water is only an inch deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands) It could have been quicksand! I might have been sucked to my death. (jumps out of the water) Where is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A forest near the Valley of Needles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blast! A thousand miles off course. Well, I was rushed. There was a certain difference of opinion concerning a venison pie. The foolish man left it sitting on his windowsill. What did he expect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps he expected to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For that rudeness, peasant lout, I am going to leave you hanging by your heels when I depart. Which is right now. >From the folds of his voluminous clothing, Ergo produces tattered spellbook. He peers at a page, mumbles to himsel and pokes his head toward Colwyn - whereupon he vanishes. Colwyn glances around but the little man is nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me down from here! Colwyn turns and sees Ergo hanging upside-down from a tre limb directly behind him. He lifts him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My spells always go wrong when I am observed. Be gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forest is not safe these days. You'd best travel with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Travel with you? I am Ergo the Magnificent ... (flattens hand) ... short in stature ... (points to the sky) ... tall in power ... (opposes thumb and forefinger) ... narrow of purpose ... (shades eyes) ... wide of vision. And I do not travel with peasants and beggars. Goodbye! We follow Ergo as he sets off down the forest path, headi in the opposite direction from Colwyn and Ynyr. After a f yards, the forest seems to grow darker, the sounds more ominous. Ergo glances around apprehensively. Suddenly, through an opening in the leaves, he sees a face with a single eye in the middle of it. With a yelp, he turns and races back up the path after Colwyn and Ynyr. When he catches up, he wedges himself between them to get as much protection as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just remembered I have urgent business in this direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fearful glance behind) Staying alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Colwyn, Ynyr, and Ergo cross the clearing, Ergo steps a snare-trigger and is suddenly hoisted into the air by h foot. Colwyn draws his sword and turns to face five armed men who step out of the forest. They're a rag-tag bunch, garbed in various kinds of chain-mail and armed with a bizarre variety of weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lad is quick, very quick. Colwyn wheels to see TORQUIL THE ROBBER leaning against a tree, his huge battle-axe resting casually across his shoulders. His cheek bulges with a wad of chewing tobacco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But also very young. Six to one is no odds, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling as he hangs upside- down) Get me down from here you louts or I'll turn you all into pigs! Torquil glances up at Ergo, then spits a stream of brown juice at the ground and steps forward to investigate his prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering as he fumbles for his spellbook) They'll soon learn the price of snaring Ergo the Magnificent. Torquil walks a circle around Colwyn and Ynyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your enemies outnumber you, boy, craft is more profitable than courage. Smile and go along and, sooner or later, they will grow careless. And then ... (throat-cutting gesture) ... sst! Colwyn sheaths his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (little smile) I don't think you'll grow careless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Smart as well as quick. Now what do you have to give us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fame? (laughs) Thank you, no. Fame is the burial ground of contentment. Eat it and go hungry; count it and go broke; seek it and grow mad. Fame is what fools yearn for and wise men shun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fame is what you leave to your sons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) How did you know I had sons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you would not rob if you had no children to provide for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah! You don't know me, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fixes him with a look) I know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colwyn) You choose these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They will be more help than high-born barons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand at the edge of the grave and make jokes. (shouts) Do you know who I am, sprout? I am Torquil, Lord of the forest. My men follow no man but me, and I follow no man at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shifts his axe) And in the few seconds before I dice you to crow-food, tell me why I am going to follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So your sons will speak of you to your grandsons, and your grandsons to their grandsons. Torquil plunks the handle of his long battle-axe into the ground, then folds his hands across the top of the blade rests his chin on his hands. He stares hard at Colwyn, wh returns his gaze calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where do you lead, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the place where Death lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) It should be an interesting journey, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answering smile) That I promise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men) I compel no man to follow me on this journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We owe you our lives, Torquil. If you follow the boy, so also do we. BARDOLPH, OSWIN, and RUHN nod their agreement. The sixth robber, SWEYN, back away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I follow the man who follows gold. He who follows glory travels without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go then, and let greed be your gravestone. Sweyn moves off into the forest. An angry oink causes the others to look up at the snare, which holds a small pig b its foot; as usual, Ergo's magic has boomeranged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have we here? (prods the pig with his axe) Roast pork for dinner. The pig squeals his objections. Torquil signals to drop t snare, and picks the pig up under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs his book. Torquil finds the open spellbook and kneels, allowing the pig to read it. Pop, and Torquil is holding a gyrating cl under his arm, replete with squeals and yells and pieces pig and Ergo; pop, and the cloud disappears, leaving Ergo under Torquil's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me down, you lout!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sets him down) You had better manners as a pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haughty) I am Ergo the Magnificent, and I do not travel with thieves and robbers. He takes two steps into the forest, then glances around anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (backing out of the forest) Except when necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the band nears the crest of the hill, Colwyn stumbles. Torquil reaches out to steady him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you last sleep, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking off the help) I'm all right. They top the hill and look out over the valley, dotted wi plumes of smoke from burning villages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They burn many villages. Even walled cities fall to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Why do they burn the villages? There's nothing to gain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's terror to gain. Their wealth is fear: they get it with fire, they spend it to rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band has stopped in the middle of the clearing. Colwy is swaying, barely able to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll stop here to hunt. Even those who don't sleep must eat. Colwyn folds his arms across his chest, tries to stand up straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes drifting shut) I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (folding his arms across his chest) Not sleepy, either?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes almost closed, swaying) No. Torquil purses his lips and blows at Colwyn, who falls backward into the arms of Kegan, who lays him gently on t ground, fast asleep. Torquil covers him with his cape. Th other robbers string their bows and prepare to hunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me a deer! No deer, no supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torquil and Ynyr talk to several PEASANTS at the edge of clearing while, in the center, Ergo tends the cooking fir beside which Colwyn lies asleep. Ergo's face lights up wh he sees Kegan arrive with a stag across his shoulders, an he snick-snacks his carving knife in anticipation. But Torquil has Kegan turn over the stag to the peasants, whi nearly gives Ergo apoplexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (galloping across the clearing) What are you doing with my dear? Stop! Thieves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (restraining him) Many villagers are hiding in the forest. They need food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you think I live on air?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have plenty of hares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorts) Food for crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely a sorcerer of the sauce pan can make rabbit taste like venison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am being exploited! Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving off with Ynyr) I must take the old man to see some sick children. Kegan will guard you. But Kegan spots a hare and creeps into the forest after i leaving Ergo and Colwyn alone in the clearing. Suddenly, Ergo hears ominous noises. He peers into the da forest and his jaw drops as he sees a pair of red eyes staring out of the gloom. He snatches up a carving knife a frying pan and backs toward Colwyn, holding the pan as shield. The red-eyed thing moves toward them through the trees, and poor Ergo is unmanned by fear: he drops his kn and ducks his head behind the frying pan in sheer terror. But he hears the thing stop short and raises his head to look behind him, where a CYCLOPS stands with trident pois to throw. The little man assumes that both creatures are trying to kill him and faints dead away. But the trident aimed at the red-eyed thing, which has no desire to do battle with the Cyclops. The thing retreats, the red eyes fade. The Cyclops comes over to Ergo and kneels to listen his heart. Then he enters the forest after the Dark One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band, including Colwyn, is gathered around Ergo, who telling his story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating positions) One with red eyes, the other with one eye, both trying to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one with red eyes was a Dark One, the other was a Cyclops, and it was not you he meant to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was aiming a huge spear right at me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that were so, you'd be dead now. He was aiming at the Dark One, for there is ancient hatred between them. Once his race had two eyes, like other men, until his forefathers bargained with the Dark Ones: they gave up one of their eyes in return for the power to see the future. But they were cheated, for the only future they were permitted to see was the time of their own death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know when they're going to die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Everyone of his race is born knowing the day of his death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowledge I wouldn't want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They are sad, solitary creatures, rarely seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once is enough, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saved our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glance toward fire) But not our supper. Ergo sees smoke rising from a pot on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running to the pot) Oh, my poor stew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my poor stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band is asleep, Torquil on guard. As the eastern hori grows light, Torquil wakes Ynyr and Colwyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn sits against a tree, brow furrowed in concentratio the golden glaive spinning in midair in front of him. Yny and Torquil look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't reach her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Tunnels and corridors. (pause) Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa moves down the windowless corridor with the white leopard at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly) Lyssa ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the Fortress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's a maze of tunnels. I can't see out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will find you. I will be with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fading) I love you, Lyssa, I love you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn. Colwyn. (in her own voice) I love you, Colwyn. RESUME - COLWYN ET. AL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't see out. She can't tell us where the Fortress is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they knew of your first contact, so they drove her below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was very faint. I was barely able to reach her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deeper she goes, the harder it is to contact her. Once she is below the second level, you will not be able to reach her at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaps to his feet, shouts angrily) I will find her! He hurls his glaive at a nearby tree: the weapon bores cl through the trunk, then through two more before it imbeds itself in a fourth. But anger gives way to despair; he buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hand on his shoulder) We'll seek an Emerald Seer. They have great powers of vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an Emerald Circle a few leagues from here. (moves to Colwyn) We'll find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up) Forgive me. It's childish to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thumbs the tears from Colwyn's cheeks) Those are not child's tear. A child cries for himself, a man cries for those he loves.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: She and the leopard are forced deeper in the Fortress, do yet another flight of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn and Torquil top the hill and look down at the lake the surface of which looks as if it had been instantly frozen in the midst of a great storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can save half a day by crossing the Stone Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming up) Many have perished in that maze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grin) No maze to me, my fried. It is where we take refuge when they hunt us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead us across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the lake, an enormous wave is poised to break, frozen in blue stone, even to the froth that caps Torquil leads the band into the maze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking beside Ynyr) I wish you'd tell me why that foolish boy decided to join up with these thieves. The little man suddenly lets out a yelp and jumps back: H is staring into the jaws of a huge shark frozen in the wa (as was all the marine life in the lake, including gulls with one foot touching the water). He steers around the j and catches up to Ynyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't join them. They joined him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who is he that they should join him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least I'm glad to see you have a sense of humor. That's the first smile I've seen on that gloomy face of your's ... (Ynyr is not smiling) ... isn't it? It isn't. Oh no. Oh dear. Oh now I've gone and done it. He scurries forward and tugs at Colwyn's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your kingship ... your lord high mightiness ... when I called you a ... a ... whatever I called you, I didn't realize that you were ... were ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping I might be your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staggered) My friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have need of friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flattered nearly senseless) No more, my lord - my friend. With Ergo the Magnificent by your side, your enemies are dead men. The little man pulls out a carving knife and, with a flourish, tucks it in his belt - slicing through his oute garment as he does so. Colwyn glances down and sees red liquid oozing from the cut. Ergo follows his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staggering) Argh! I'm dying! Colwyn notices seeds oozing out with the liquid and sampl it with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, my friend. It's your tomato that's dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Oh no! Better it was me. There isn't another good tomato within a hundred leagues. He pulls out the stabbed tomato and kisses it tearfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my poor baby. He looks up to see Ynyr smiling broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowling) I liked you better gloomy, old man. Colwyn resumes his place beside Torquil, who gives him a sideways glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. You're something more than a seeker of fame. Colwyn shrugs sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I knew you would not be. That's why I chose you. They reach the end of the lake, which is bordered by a sm scarp. Torquil hikes himself onto the scarp and reaches d to help Colwyn up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grin) I'm a little impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circle of stone dolmens, emerald green, in the center o which sits an old man, blind, wearing a green robe: an EMERALD SEER. Sitting across from him is TITCH, his ten- year-old assistant, similarly robed. A green-hued holographic image appears above the emerald, showing Colwyn and his band approaching. The Seer weaves fingers through the image, reading it by touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight come here, Brother. They have traveled far. Fetch bread and wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Brother. The boy fetches a jug of wine and a round loaf of bread, approaches Colwyn's band as they enter the stone circle. Colwyn waves Titch toward his men and moves with Ynyr and Torquil to the Seer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We seek the Fortress of Krull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a vision will be opposed. Who seeks it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (little smile) With an old voice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answering smile) You know the voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You have left your place in the Needle. It is the time, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will seek the Fortress for you. The Seer presses his fingertips against the rotating sphe increasing the pressure and friction until small tongues flame spurt from beneath his fingertips. A holograph begins to form above the sphere: the Fortress mid-ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It is the Western Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a prisoner there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The holograph dissolves, replaced by a new one which show curving Arm of the Vortex, the deep, central parts of the Fortress. Lyssa and the white leopard move down the Arm, pressed by an unseen pursuer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) Lyssa. As the twin suns dip below the horizon, the flames spurti from the Seer's fingertips begin to leap and lengthen, un the sphere is surrounded by fire, its color changing from emerald-green to crimson. We hear faint, hollow screams o rage. The holograph above the sphere begins to waver and blur, then is shattered by a holographic black claw shooting upward from the sphere. The talons of the claw are blood red, its appearance accompanied by a hollow scream. The Seer is knocked backward; the claw disappears; the emerald drops to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kneeling by the Seer) Are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up) No. (grim smile) The Dark Ones do not like curious Seers poking into their affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell us where the Fortress will rise tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot see the future, only the present. But at dawn tomorrow, I can see where the fortress has risen that day - and every day thereafter, until Fate brings it near us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dark Ones will appose you with all their power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will fail for, during the day, the power of the Circle is greater than theirs. Only at night can they pierce the Circle. Titch approaches Ergo with bread and wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrinkling his nose) Bread is for peasants, and wine makes me sneeze. Got any gumdrops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugarballs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What kind of a boy are you? Boys always have candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a cinnamon bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (producing the bar) You can have half. Ergo takes the bar and breaks it into unequal parts. He i about to take the bigger piece for himself when conscienc gets the better of him; reluctantly, he offers the bigger piece to Titch. But the boy takes the small piece, leavin the delighted Ergo with the lion's share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full) I am Ergo the Magnificent ... (flattens hand) ... short in stature ... (points to sky) ... tall in power ... (opposes thumb and forefinger) ... narrow of purpose ... (shades eyes) ... wide of vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full, points to his chest) I ... (bows from waist) ... am Titch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Ergo and Titch tend the cooking fire, robbers leave hunt and others return with small game. Sitting against one of the stone dolmens, Colwyn tries to contact Lyssa, the glaive spinning in midair in front of him. Ynyr and Torquil look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot reach her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is too deep. The curved tunnel we saw is part of the Vortex, the place of The Beast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leader of the Dark Ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (to Colwyn) Like you, a King. A King of many worlds. All enslaved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time, when they attacked long ago, was The Beast here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Then they were led by his underlings. But I knew he had come this time, from the ferocity of their onslaught, from their use of The Fortress. They use up much of their strength to do these things. They are taking great risks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evasive) I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will know, in good time. At the cooking fire, Kegan arrives with a string of small game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Rabbits and squirrels. Where is my deer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw nothing but does and fawns, and we shoot only stags. Kegan lays down the string of game and moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbling) Nothing worse than lower-class boors with upper-class morals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you settle for a boar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Titch) A boar? Those incompetent louts couldn't catch a piglet, much less a boar. He realizes that the voice has come from behind him and turns to see the Cyclops with a huge boar slung across hi shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. (lays down the boar) May I eat with you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight and every night, my friend, for this is the second time you've saved my life. (draws himself up) I am Ergo the Magnificent, short in stature, tall in power, etcetera, etcetera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Quell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart lad. (theatrical) Bring me my spices! Titch hands him a leather belt of spices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must fetch my master. (smiles at Cyclops as he passes) I'm Titch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Seer kneels at water's edge, washing his hands with ritual motions. He hears footsteps behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you, Brother? We see a CHANGELING/SEER standing behind him: an exact tw except that his eyes are open and red. Changeling reaches down and places his hand on the Seer's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hiss) It is me, Brother. His hand turns into a taloned claw, which tightens around the Seer's neck, throttling him. He lowers the body into stream, then reaches into the Seer's robe and extracts th emerald, which he crushes in his claw. The green fragment drop into the water, floating downstream behind the Seer' body. His bloody claw now reverts to human form, but the finger remain bloody. He kneels and washes off the blood. When h hears Titch approaching, he closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Seer's voice) Is that you, Brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is me, Brother. He stands and places his hand on the boy's shoulder to be led back to camp. The Cyclops appears, having followed Ti to guard him. The Cyclops glances at the Changeling, but notices nothin unusual. He takes a few steps farther down the path, to check it out - and stops just short of a point that would show him the Seer's body fetched up against a rock in the stream. He turns and follows Titch back to the campsite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band is seated around the fire, finishing a huge dinn of roast boar. The Changeling/Seer sits slightly apart, h eye-lids lifting occasionally to afford a thin slit, thro which he surveys the group with red eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising a joint) Passable, pimple, very passable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greatest boon of your otherwise worthless life, blockhead, is the privilege of dining on boar roasted by the hand of Ergo the Magnificent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boast is a bigger mouthful than your roast, Magnificence. He glances over his shoulder at Colwyn, who is leaning against a dolmen, staring gloomily into the darkness. Torquil gets up and goes to him, carrying the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've eaten nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrug, pause) We must try to get horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It will double our range. (grins) I know at least a dozen ways to get horses. All cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (little smile) These we'll pay for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sigh) Lad, you have an unnatural desire to pay for things. It stunts the mind and shrivels the imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thumb in his ribs) Hand over your dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands it over) A flicker of talent. Colwyn's hunger comes alive as he starts to work on the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't tell yet whether it's a talent for theft or gluttony. Ergo, Titch, and the Cyclops, full to bursting, are stretched out together beside the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could wish ... (belch) ... for anything, I'd wish for a venison pie the size of a ... (belch) ... mountain. No, that's too greedy. I'd settle for one the size of a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd wish for a puppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One puppy? Why not wish for a hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only want one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A foolish wish. And you, Quell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bardolph and Oswin stand guard over the sleeping band, stationed at the perimeter of the Circle, looking outward The Cyclops broods by the fire, his expression troubled. frowns and looks around, then gets up and moves out of th Circle into the darkness. As soon as the Cyclops is gone, the Changeling/Seer opens his eyes and looks around. He stands and moves toward Bardolph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns) Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out a hand) It's me, Brother. I am thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, I'll guide you. He approaches the Changeling, who places a hand on his shoulder to be led to the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they move down the path, the Changeling's hand turns i a claw and he throttles Bardolph so quickly he's unable t utter a sound. He tosses the body into the bushes and sta to wipe his bloody hand on the grass - but stands as he hears Colwyn coming down the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Bardolph, Brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heard something and went to investigate, Brother. Colwyn starts to move past him to the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching out) Lead me to the stream, Brother. Colwyn stops and allows the Changeling to place a hand on his shoulder. A close shot of the Changeling's hand shows still bloody, the blood running onto the cloth of Colwyn' jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cyclops stands near the spot where the real Seer was killed. He moves downstream a few yards - and suddenly se the Seer's body floating in the water, caught against the rocks. He realizes immediately that the band is in great danger; he races up the path toward the camp. As Colwn leads the Changeling down the path, we see the h on his shoulder turn into a claw. The claw is moving towa his neck when suddenly the Cyclops bursts from the trees front of them. Colwyn stares in disbelief as the Cyclops hurls his trident straight at him. The weapon whistles pa his ear and slices off the Changeling's arm at the should Colwyn spins, sees the red eyes, ducks backward as the Changeling swipes at him with his other hand - now become claw. He draws his glaive as the Changeling reverts entir to bestial form, its hideous black body bursting the seam of the emerald-green robe. As the creature springs at Colwyn, we see, for an instant the horrible face: teeth flashing, eyes burning. Then Colwyn's glaive strikes between the eyes. Slit by the horizontal blades of the glaive, the eyes explode in a bu of red and the thing dies with a scream. Torquil, Ynyr, and others run up. The body of the creatur has already turned to ash, forming the characteristic Vor of the Dark Ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ynyr) A Changeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It chose the Seer's form so it wouldn't have to show its eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cyclops) How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found the body of the Seer in the stream. They all look up the path at Titch, who is rubbing his ey sleepily. Ergo goes up to him and puts an arm around his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band stands beside a fresh grave, outlined by stone markers. Colwyn is kneeling with his arms around Titch, whose face is buried against his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he had not agreed to help us, they would not have killed him. He gave his life for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my only family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're your family now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn, Ynyr, and Torquil sit by the fire while the other sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go to the widow. Perhaps she will help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Widow of the Web?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That creature helps no one. And none who go there return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has the power of vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has the power to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps she will not kill me, for I know her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name is Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had another name once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with finality) No. We will find another way to locate the Fortress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no other way. You asked me why the Beast had come this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has come for Lyssa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you, she has extraordinary powers. He would make her his Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can she be forced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She must agree of her own free will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are young. You don't understand the attraction of great power, and you forget the pain of long waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we must reach her before she feels that pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. On the other side of the fire, Ergo lies awake, watching Titch, who is asleep next to him, his face tear-stained. Cyclops sits nearby, leaning against a stone, one hand on his trident. His eye is closed; he appears to be asleep. Ergo sits up, takes his spellbook, and sneaks off behind stone. The Cyclops opens his eye and watches as Ergo thum through the book, mumbles a spell, and disappears in a gyrating white cloud. When the cloud disappears, Ergo has transformed himself into a puppy. The puppy trots over to the sleeping Titch and licks his face. The boy stirs, ope his eyes, and hugs the puppy to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red eyes press Lyssa and the leopard down the curving passage-way until they emerge in the center of the vortex

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arms open into the top of a huge bloodstone funnel, a the bottom of which is the hole of the Beast. Lyssa and h guardian are forced along a spiral walkway that curves do the walls of the funnel to the dark hole at the bottom. We hear a heavy, slithering sound, as of an enormous tail being dragged across stone. A pair of huge red eyes appea in the Beast's hole and we hear a husky whisper: the soun is ominous, but also attractive, in the way that enormous power is always attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not be afraid. You are safe here. You are protected by my power. Lyssa shrinks against the stone. The white leopard roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not one of those trivial ones who have been guarding you. They are my slaves. They are to me as drops to an ocean. I rule here. The leopard leaps at the hole, but is frozen in mid-leap, suspended in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rule all here. The leopard is suddenly flung backward, hurled with tremendous force against the stone. Lyssa turns to see it embedded in the solid rock, mouth open and eyes glazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nature is my slave here. A stone claw rises from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its laws are mine to break. The claw bursts into flame and strikes at Lyssa with such force that the rock around her is shattered, yet she is unharmed. The flaming claw lifts her up and sets her down then shrinks to a ball of flame and drops into her hand; looks down to see that she is holding a rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such is my power. It can be yours. When she looks up, the red eyes are gone. She is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the camp wakes, the puppy crawls out of Titch's ar and trots behind the stone. It scans the spellbook lying open on the ground, then disappears in a gyrating white cloud and becomes Ergo again. As he sneaks back to his ow blanket, he sees the Cyclops watching him with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbling) I still say it was a foolish wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band makes its way past the Swamp, heading for the Widow's Mountain, visible in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glance toward Swamp) What is that awful looking place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swamp of Betrayal. Be glad we don't have to cross it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad. (glance toward Swamp) I'm very glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concealed at the side of the road are ten Slayers and Swe the robber who refused to go along with the band. He poin down the road at the approaching band. The Chief Slayer nods, and hands him a leather purse full of gold coins, which Sweyn tucks in his jacket. They mount their horses start down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slayers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must enter the swamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few have survived it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Slayers) Fewer will survive them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's our only chance. They can't use their horses there. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mangrove swamp, with a lattice-work of gnarled roots hovering above dark waters. The band enters the swamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not let the waters touch you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be devoured by your own mind. Colwyn and Torquil help the old man, Ynyr, while the Cycl takes care of the two little ones, Ergo and Titch, someti lifting one in each hand to deposit them on the next root The Slayers reach the edge of the Swamp and dismount. Swe and the Chief Slayer lead them in. The band is halfway across the Swamp when Colwyn suddenly slips and plunges into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extends a hand) Take hold! But the waters of betrayal have begun their work:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Torquil stand and embrace Lyssa, who comes from behind a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him drown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Then we'll marry and you will be my king. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOT
dialogues.text: Colwyn draws his sword and swings at Torquil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traitor! She'll marry you in hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Torquil) He thinks you betray him with Lyssa. (to Colwyn) Colwyn! The waters deceive you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Ynyr stand and talk to someone behind the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have delivered him into your hands. Now pay me the price we agreed on. A black claw appears, pouring gold coins into Ynyr's hand

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOT
dialogues.text: Colwyn lunges at Ynyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will melt that gold and pour it down your throat, old man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees betrayal everywhere. He will attack us so long as he is conscious. They glance anxiously at the Slayers, closing quickly. Ti reaches into Ergo's voluminous coat and pulls out a soup ladle, which he throws at Colwyn. The ladle catches Colwy in the forehead, knocking him unconscious - but also knocking him backward in the water, out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Torquil) Your axe! Lay it out! Torquil tucks the heel of the axe handle under a root and grips it with both hands. Ergo tightropes out the handle kneels on the axe head, directly above Colwyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hold the weight of both of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush! He squinches his eyes shut and mumbles something to himse The gyrating white cloud appears with a pop and, when it pops off, Ergo has been transformed into a snake, with it tail wrapped around the axe handle. The snakes plunges in the water and wraps itself around Colwyn's chest. Torquil grits his teeth and pulls up on the axe, lifting the snak and Colwyn out of the water and depositing them on a nexu of roots. The white cloud reappears and returns Ergo to human form, barely conscious, coughing and spitting water. Meanwhile, the Slayers are almost upon them. The Cyclops moved to the rear with Kegan, Oswin, and Rhu. As the Chie Slayer comes within range, the Cyclops lunges with his trident, slicing the root on which the Slayer stands and spilling him into the dark waters. Sweyn kneels to help h out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traitor! He stabs Sweyn in the chest, slicing through the purse of gold coins. Sweyn tumbles into the water, blood and gold pouring out of the gash in his jacket. The Chief Slayer attacks the others, wounding some, knocking several into water - and they, in turn, attack their fellows. The band stares in awed silence as the Slayers massacre e other. The din of battle fades; the Slayers, dead to a ma float in the water. As Colwyn regains consciousness, the others gather round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, my friends. I saw terrible things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do not exist, except in the waters of the Swamp, where they will remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band emerges from the Swamp, which laps at the foot o the Widow's Mountain. Ynyr faces Colwyn and Torquil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From here, I must go alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will tell me her name and we will go together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with peculiar emphasis) You must never know her name. (pause) If more than one approaches, she will certainly kill them. Alone I may have a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hand on Colwyn's shoulder) Each to his fate, lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Each to his fate. Wait for me at the inn. If I am not back by dawn, you will know my fate, and you must go on without me. He turns and starts up the mountain. At the rear of the group, the Cyclops heads toward a fore carrying Titch on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll meet you at the inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) Can't I come, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The Cyclops moves off with Titch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Titch rides on the Cyclop's shoulders, straddling his nec He holds a small crossbow at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers and points) Over there. Titch takes aim at a great stag, bracing his arm against top of the Cyclops's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kegan, Oswin, and Rhun are downing flagons of sack and dandling pretty INN-GIRLS on their knees. Torquil eyes th enviously from the fireplace across the room, but can't bring himself to leave Colwyn, who takes no comfort from wine or women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of friend do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best. But my unhappiness is not made lighter by adding your's to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it is true that if I received a royal command I couldn't very well disobey it, could I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (little smile) Go. I command you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Yes, my lord. He strides across the room, seizes a pair of Inn-Girls by the waist and swings them around. Ergo, sitting near Colwyn, stares despondently into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try your tricks on me and I'll turn myself back into a snake and bite you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I will guard the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else is left for a man without friends. Colwyn glances out a back window and sees the body of a s being carried past on someone's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
