dialogues.text: Ynyr climbs toward the hourglass opening of the Widow's c above, lit by an eerie light from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gigantic web of crystal stretches across a vast, domed cavern, shimmering in the luminescence from below. At the center of the web is a domed cubicle, made of criss-cross ribbons of mirror glass. Light flashes off the mirrors in such a way that it is impossible to see, through the openings, who or what is within. The blinding effect does not occur inside the cubicle, so that a POV SHOT from inside shows the entire web clearly. also shows, reflected from hundreds of facets on the insi of the structure, the face of the WIDOW, the old woman wh sits at the center: a hideous crone, grotesque and distorted. She sees Ynyr standing at the edge of the web.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Someone comes here. She picks up an hourglass, containing only a handful of sand, and turns it to start the sand running out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is his time. Ynyr is shouting at her from the edge of the web.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) I am Ynyr. I seek the Widow. But sound does not pierce the cubicle. From inside it, on can only see his lips moving. Ynyr steps onto the web and starts toward the center. Whe he's halfway across, he turns to see a giant black widow spider made of crystal, entirely translucent except for a red hourglass in the center of its crystal abdomen. As th spider approaches Ynyr and prepares to attack, the red co expands, filling the abdomen first, then spreading throug the rest of the body. Ynyr holds up his glaive. The spider stops, begins moving sideways; the redness fades. Inside the cubicle, the hourglass sand has almost run out. The spider twitches a crystal strand, throwing Ynyr off balance and causing the glaive to fly from his hand. It sticks in a crystal strand, too far to reach. Ynyr is helpless. The spider advances, reddening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate shout) Lyssa! This name has the power to pierce the soundproof cubicle: the Widow stands as she hears the name, ECHOED by the hug cavern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls) Who speaks that name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Ynyr! She watches as the spider looms over Ynyr. Then she reach behind her and turns the hourglass, just as the last grai of sand run out. This causes the spider to back away, turning translucent again. Ynyr retrieves the glaive and makes his way to the domed cubicle. He enters the cubicle to find the Widow facing away from him, though he can see her hideous face reflected back by the mirrors in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is fifty years since I heard that name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is fifty years since I spoke it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was beautiful then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most beautiful woman in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you would not stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could not. Could not betray the girl to whom I was betrothed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was not as beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she was not as beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bore you many children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had no children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staggered) You said nothing. You told me nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had left me! I kept silent out of rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? My son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed him when he was born. (pause) This place is my punishment. The old man bends his head sadly. When he looks up, he se in the mirrors that tears are coursing down the Widow's cheek. As he watches the tears, the mirrored face turns t that of a beautiful young girl. And the Widow is stunned find that she sees the reflections as he sees them: the f of a young girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not try your trickery on me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is no trickery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are reflections. (turns to face him) This is my face! When she starts to turn, we SEE her as old. But when she faces Ynyr, we SEE her THROUGH HIS EYES: as a young girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes. A REVERSE ANGLE explains her smile: she sees him as the young man who loved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memory is no trick, it is a power. The power to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power you have given me. What can my power give you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fortress of Krull. When will it come near here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a girl there. Her name is Lyssa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches her cheek) Could I lie to you and still see your beauty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lowers her eyes) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man seeks her. A young man about the age I was when I met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, the Fortress of Krull will rise with the sun in the Valley of Reeds. But the knowledge is of no use to you. No man has ever escaped the Web. And soon the creature will come for you, even here. Ynyr touches his glaive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) It will not help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the other Lyssa will share your fate. She will grow old in the Fortress as you have grown old here. The Widow takes a small gold hourglass from a mirrored niche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold out your hand. She breaks the hourglass and pours the sand into his open hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are the sands of my life. So long as they remain in your hand, the creature cannot harm you. Ynyr closes his hand, but the sand trickles out through h fingers. He tries clenching it tightly, but the sand continues to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot stop the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot stop time. Go now, before it runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is sand enough for only one life. Go now, save the other. She watches Ynyr make his way across the web toward the c entrance. The ANGLE is BEHIND HER, and we SEE her hands g gnarled and mottled, her body become that of an old woman once again - but when we SWING AROUND IN FRONT OF HER, we SEE that her face is still that of a young girl. The crystal spider scuttles across the web to attack Ynyr But the old man holds up his clenched fist and shows the sand running from his fingers. Stymied, the spider crouches and turns blood red. A screa of rage fills the cave. Ynyr reaches the safety of the entrance and looks back: t blood-red spider scuttles to the center of the web and smashes open the cubicle. Ynyr looks at his hand: the san has run out. As the old man makes his way sadly down the mountain ...

dialogues.speaker: A SHOT OF THE WIDOW
dialogues.text: Shows her encased in a web shroud; and though her body is old, she retains, even in death, the face of a young girl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torquil and his men dandle INN GIRLS on their knees, laughing, leching, and guzzling. The INNKEEPER bustles about, assisted by a much-abused serving girl named VEELA whose beauty is concealed by kerchiefed hair, frumpy clothes, and a layer of soot. Across the room, Colwyn and Ergo sit in front of the fire staring gloomily into the flames. Titch comes in the back door and whispers to Torquil, who signals his men. They get up and head for the back wall, where Cyclops is swinging open a pair of large double doo Ergo is too glum to notice the sudden diminution of noise but Colwyn sees Torquil and his men carrying in a giant venison pie, ten feet across and five feet high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comes up to Ergo) Ergo? The little man hunches forward, refusing to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Ergo? ... My honorable Lord Ergo? ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, you desert me, and now you mock me. Go back to your one-eyed friend. Titch reaches out and presses the end of Ergo's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Now you poke me in the nose as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not working? This nose? This nose works day and night. This nose has never loafed an hour in its life. This nose ... (sniffs) What? (sniffs again) Impossible. This nose asleep while venison fills the air? (seizes Titch) Where is it, boy? Tell me where it is and I forgive you everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right behind you. Ergo turns and his eyes grow as big as the pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awed whisper) A venison pie as big as a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you think a small person lives in, you one-eyed fool? Leaving me here to mope while you and the boy were arranging my assassination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We meant only to please you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you think I'm not going to eat myself to death this very night? Huh? The dwarf approaches the pie worshipfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at its beauty. Look at its grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds out a knife) Look at its insides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Not yet! Let me hug it and kiss it a little.  Let me run my fingers over its lovely skin. (climbs onto the pie) Let me climb to the top and sing to it. He clambers up the crust and stands on top of the pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henceforth I am Lord Ergo, for now I have an estate to rule. He kneels and embraces the crust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crooning) Let us go then, you and I, my sweet and hot and lovely pie ... The crust suddenly gives way beneath him; he plunges into the pie, disappearing completely. The onlookers laugh and applaud. But when he doesn't reappear, they grow worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knocks on the crust) Ergo? Are you all right? Ergo's head pops up through the crust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here lies Lord Ergo, drowned in a venison pie. He died with a smile and a belch, goodbye, goodbye ... He disappears inside the pie again. The others crowd arou and begin dismembering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn and the Cyclops stand guard over sleeping robbers inn girls. Ergo floats half-awake in the gravy in the pie shell, a contented smile on his face. He opens his mouth allows a piece of venison to float into it. Then he hears whimpering and peers over the edge of the crust: Titch is asleep nearby, in the throws of a nightmare. The serving girl, Vella, is still busy cleaning up. As sh passes the pie shell, she hears scrabbling and splashing, and stops to see a puppy trying to clamber out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift him out. Vella lifts out the puppy and sets it on the floor. The puppy shakes itself, then trots over to Titch. The boy hu the puppy to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cyclops) It's the little man called Ergo, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must care a lot for the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming over) You lazy slut! I don't pay you to stand around jawing with the guests!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave her be. She's worked hard all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll work till dawn if I choose! He cuffs the girl, knocking her to the floor, but backs a as Colwyn approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an order) Her working day is over. She'll rest now. The Innkeeper scowls, then skulks off, grumbling. Colwyn helps the girl up and sees that her ankle has been twiste by her fall. He puts an arm around her and helps her towa the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa moves around the walkway, looking for escape, but a the passages leading out of the Center are blocked by red eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you considered? She turns to see the gigantic red eyes in the Beast's hol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not want your power. It is hideous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know nothing of power, you foolish girl. You think power is a mighty sword, or a strong castle, or the paltry magic of an Emerald Seer. Power is none of these. The red eyes in the hole disappear. Lyssa hears the voice behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power is beauty. She turns to see a Greek Adonis standing behind her. His naked body glistens with oil; he is incredibly handsome. (But his eyes are red.) She retreats. The Adonis vanishes and Lyssa feels her hand clasped gently. She turns to see girl of her own age, smiling at her. (But her eyes are re and she speaks with the Voice of Darkness.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power is friendship. When Lyssa pulls her hand away, the girl vanishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power is joy. Lyssa sees herself (but with red eyes) as a young mother, holding a baby and laughing. Then she feels a hand on her cheek and turns to see Colwy (red-eyes), smiling at her as he caresses her cheek. He speaks with the dark Voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power is desire. She knows, from the eyes and voice, that this is not the real Colwyn. But loneliness and fear and longing are beginning to take their toll. She touches his hand, press it against her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cruelest fate is to be far from the one you love, not knowing whether you will ever see him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vella sits dejectedly on the edge of the bed. Colwyn stan near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was betrothed to a boy from my village. We were to be married this summer, but he traveled across the sea and his ship was lost. (bows her head, whispers) They say he drowned, but I know he is alive. I know he will come back to me. Moved by her grief, Colwyn sits on the bed and takes her his arms to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the cruelty of such a fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifts her head) Perhaps you think no man would return to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that. Vella stands and slips the kerchief from around her hair, which is long and lustrous. It tumbles loose, falling gracefully around her shoulders. She wipes the sleeve acr her face and, almost magically, the smudges and dirt disappear. She steps out of her ungainly shoes, then unfastens her ugly dress; it falls to her feet. She stand barefoot in her chemise, stunningly beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I not worth returning to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I not beautiful enough to be loved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even by you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drops his eyes) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red-eyed Colwyn holds Lyssa's hand as he makes his proposal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This I tell you: our children will be princes. They will have the power of my darkness and the power of your blood. They will conquer galaxies. Lyssa back away, shaking her head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will make you a queen. A queen of worlds uncountable. The red-eyed Colwyn waves his hand and a stone wall crack open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the galaxies you will rule. Through the crack, we see galaxies moving toward us, slow at first, then faster. We see not only the familiar galac forms - spirals, ellipses, spheres - but shapes and color never seen from Earth: exploding galaxies of red stars, whirling galaxies of yellow and blue, galaxies writhing a if in pain. They move toward us, faster and faster, until they becomes blurs of light and color. Another wall crack open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the worlds of your empire. We see planets moving toward us: Earthlike planets of blu and green, volcanic planets spitting flame, gaseous plane ringed planets, planets with a hundred moons. Another wal cracks open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the beings who will be your slaves. We see crowds of living creatures, some humanoid, others with shapes never seen, prostrating themselves in obeisan keening their pain and fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not want your worlds or your slaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then look! Another wall cracks open. We see Colwyn and Vella in a cl embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These walls do not lie! He will betray you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he will die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn and Vella in each other's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too are lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ache with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me comfort you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot take comfort when she has none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then give me comfort. Sleep with me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot betray my bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One night is no betrayal. Have pity on me. (begins to cry) Please, I beg you, do not refuse me. You do not know the price. Her tears wash the blue dye from her eyes and we see that her eyes are red. Colwyn is in the arms of a Dark One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel your pain, but I cannot betray her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot. Vella's left hand turns into a claw. She moves it toward neck, then stops. She begins to cry; blood-red tears run down her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My master told me: make him betray her; if he will not, kill him. Colwyn steps back from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrusts out her claw) Yes, he is my master. Colwyn plucks his glaive from his belt and poises it to throw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These talons were a heartbeat from your throat. I could have killed you in an instant. Colwyn lowers the glaive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in the hour I knew you, I loved you. That love is life for you and death for me. Remember me. In the Vortex, Lyssa stares defiantly at the red-eyed Colwyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is you who are betrayed. The red-eyed Colwyn extends his left hand, which turns in a claw; the talons clutch the empty air - and in her room Vella gasps as she is strangled. The red-eyed Colwyn snaps his arm sideways - and Vella is flung across her room against the wall. Her body disintegrates, leaving only gray ash and an empty chemise

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have faith, Lyssa. I will come. In the Vortex, the false Colwyn has vanished. The huge re eyes have reappeared in the Beast's hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will come for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will not come. You will be my queen. The eyes recede, accompanied by the heavy, slithering sou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the twin suns edge above the horizon, the black, hulki Fortress of Krull rises majestically above the reeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ynyr, having just returned from the mountain, confers wit the band outside the inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must reach the Valley of Reeds before the next dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hundred leagues from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could reach it on fire-mares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those beasts cannot be saddled by mortal men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can be saddled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have done it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I road them often in my youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Torquil) Saddles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The innkeeper. As Colwyn and Torquil move toward the inn, Ynyr draws the Cyclops aside, glancing at the bands of white linen on hi wrists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low, to Cyclops) It is dangerous for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will only be a few hours. Then I will accept my fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band watches from the edge of the marsh as the Cyclop stands knee-deep in water, facing the charge of a dozen fire-mares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll trample him to death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He will master the leader. The fire-mares charge past the Cyclops, who disappears in cloud of smoke and steam and spray. They wheel and charge again, circling him. He fixes his eyes on the lead mare, pulls out of the circle and comes toward him. The Cyclops places his hand on the mare's muzzle and the horse stands quietly. The others follow suit, forming a circle around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band is mounted, except for the Cyclops. Titch sits behind Colwyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls) Quell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot go with you, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It is today. The band files past him, each man reaching down to shake hand. Ergo is next to last. His mouth works as he tries t speak, but no words come out. The Cyclops embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My heart stays here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And mine goes with you. Ergo moves off, wiping his nose on his sleeve. Colwyn is last, with Titch sitting behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Titch) You're too young to come with us, lad. Stay with our friend. He swings the boy to the ground, then grips the Cyclops's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each to his fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each to his fate. The Cyclops stands beside Titch, holding the boy's hand, watching the band move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colwyn, as they ride) He ran a great risk, helping us today. If he opposes his fate, his death will be terribly painful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back) Let us wish him peace. The Cyclops is sitting cross-legged on the ground, having wound a white linen headband around his forehead. Titch s beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing up) We must cover a hundred leagues before sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stand in his stirrups) At the gallop! As the mares increase their speed, their sparking hooves begin to flash, until, at full gallop, their feet and fetlocks are enveloped in flame. They thunder down the ro on a carpet of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In long shot, we see the fire-mares silhouetted against t darkening sky, galloping along the spine of the ridge on thin line of flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GATEKEEPER comes out of his hut as he hears approaching hoof-beats. A wooden gate stretches across the road, barr the ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) If they're nobles, it'll cost 'em gold. The Gatekeeper's mouth drops as the fire-mares round the curve and smash through the gate, causing the stream to b and hiss as they gallop through it. He stares at the clou of steam that mark their passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (plaintive whine) I would've settled for silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With hoofbeats audible in the distance, half a dozen THIE huddle on the log road, preparing an ambush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your places. If they resist, show no mercy! The thieves kneel at the edge of the log road, weapons at the ready. The Leader stands in the middle of the road, notches an arrow, and draws his bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold, or you are dead men! His eyes turn to saucers as the fire-mares round the curv and bear down on him. He yelps and dives into the swamp, along with the rest of his band. The fire-mares thunder past, leaving the thieves gulping swamp-water and the log road in flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horizon shows light gray as the fire-mares streak acr the valley, leaving a trail of blazing reeds. Two dozen Slayers ride from the Fortress to oppose them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts to Torquil) It's almost dawn! Flank them! Torquil leads half the band to the right, Colwyn leads th other half to the left. They sweep past the Slayers on either side, surrounding them with a ring of fire. The Slayers are enveloped by flames as the band reconverges a heads toward the high wall of the Fortress. But a dismounted Slayer pierces the fiery wall, his cloth flaming, and hurls a spear at Rhun at the tail of the ban Colwyn and Torquil look back and see Rhun skewered by the spear, the point protruding from his chest. Torquil shake his head and they continue toward the wall. But atop the wall, hidden behind the crenellated parapet, wait another dozen Slayers with cauldrons of boiling pitc at the ready. Colwyn reaches the bottom of the wall and swings off his mare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the wall! Quickly! The others dismount and follow him up the wall, which is canted back some twenty degrees from the vertical, allowi them to clamber up the stone courses. But suddenly a stre of boiling pitch pours down the wall toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out! They dodge the hissing steam of pitch, but a second strea catches Oswin, who screams as he's enveloped by the boili liquid. Colwyn and Torquil look up to see a cauldron of pitch bei moved into position directly above them. But Torquil poin down the wall where ... ... the Cyclops is galloping along the parapet, the hoove of his fire-mare sparking against the stone. Titch stands the saddle behind him, with a crossbow laid across his br shoulder. The boy looses a bolt and hits one of the Slaye at the cauldron, saving Colwyn and Torquil. The Slayers loose a hail of arrows, several of which stri the Cyclops in the chest. But he keeps coming, and Titch keeps firing bolts from behind his shoulder, felling Slay like deer. As the twin suns are about to rise, the Slayers overturn great cauldron of pitch, which pours down the wall, headi straight for Colwyn ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fortress rises out of the ice and Colwyn looks up to the stream of pitch frozen solid, not three feet above th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) On them! He leads the band up the wall to the parapet, where the Cyclops has dismounted and is holding off several Slayers shielding Titch, who is still firing his deadly bolts. A brief but fierce battle disposes of the Slayers. The band gathers around the fallen Cyclops. A dozen broke off arrow shafts protrude from his body. He holds Ergo's small hand in one of his great paws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dying smile) A man can ask nothing more than that his death help his friends. His hand tightens with the pain that he has brought upon himself, then his fingers open slowly. Ergo stifles a sob the great eye closes in death. Torquil calls Colwyn's attention to yet another group of Slayers in the distance. Colwyn leads the band across an bridge to a stone door encased in ice. They hack through ice and swing open the door, which opens onto a set of st stairs leading down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glance toward Slayers) I'll stay behind and keep them busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not necessary. They will not follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band moves down the stairs. Above, the Slayers reach the stone door, but they're clea reluctant to descend. One steps forward and starts down - but then hears the eerie screams of the Dark Ones below. scurries back up and, with the others, backs away from th door. On the stairs below, the eerie screams are deafening, echoing through the stone corridors. Ynyr leads the band, taking them down the stairs, across a landing, and down another flight of stairs. Torquil notices mortar crumbling between the stones of th staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they are weakening. It takes great power to maintain the Fortress, and they have expended much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band hurries down the corridor, pursued by dozens of eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back) They're gaining on us. (draws his sword) We must slow them up with steel. They are standing beneath a Romanesque arch that supports the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up at the arch) Better stone than steel. He draws his sword and inserts it beside the capstone of arch, working the blade to loosen the mortar. Torquil follows his thought and begins chopping at the mortar on other side of the capstone. The red eyes are almost on them when they finally succeed dislodging the capstone. They jump back as the capstone falls and the arch collapses, blocking the corridor with wall of stone rubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're resourceful, my lad. (grins) I tell you, one year under my tutelage and I could make you the Prince of Thieves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subject to the King, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (modest bow) Naturally. Suddenly, a black claw bursts from the stone rubble and clutches Torquil by the neck. Colwyn quickly draws his sw and hacks off the arm, which disintegrates into gray ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fingering his neck) A good thrust, my friend. Another second and there'd have been nothing between my head and shoulders but bad memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to keep you alive, your majesty. So you can abdicate your throne and become my Warlord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. If the pay is good. Colwyn signals Ynyr, who leads the group down the corrido and then down yet another flight of stone stairs. They emerge in ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pillared cave, pitch black. We hear the rasping sound o labored breathing, as of old men close to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls softly) Stay together. They move through the cave, weapons at the ready. A feebl voice calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torquil ... Torquil turns to see a wizened, hollow-eyed old man: hims at the end of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not let this happen, Torquil. A PRIESTESS OF YOUTH steps out from behind a pillar: she eighteen, wearing a transparent garment that shows the stunning beauty of her young body. She holds a golden gob containing a rainbow-colored liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It need not happen, Torquil. Drink the rainbow. It is youth. She reaches behind the pillar and takes the hand of YOUNG TORQUIL, pulling him into view: it is Torquil as he was a eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is your youth, Torquil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches Torquil) This is the Cavern of Age. Touch nothing, take nothing, or the future will be plunged into your heart. Torquil shudders as he looks at the old man he will becom horrified by the gaping face of his own future. Colwyn ta his arm and gently pulls him away. But the Priestess of Youth slips ahead, appearing again with the Young Torquil this time in passionate embrace. As she caresses the yout she holds out the goblet to Torquil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink the rainbow, Torquil. Youth is yours. I am yours. Take me, Torquil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guiding him past) She lies, my friend. Now it is Ergo's turn to confront the future. He sees himself as an old man, bald and shrunken, at the edge of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ergo, save yourself. Save yourself from this. >From behind a pillar appears a FAIRY PRIESTESS OF YOUTH, golden-haired, beautiful, holding a gold goblet. She tilt the goblet and pours some of the rainbow liquid into her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds out her cupped hand) Drink from my hand, Ergo. I can save you. Ergo starts toward her, but Titch grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yanking him back) Ergo! Ergo allows himself to be pulled along, gazing back wistfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she was so beautiful - and I was so ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you desert your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking himself out of it) No, no. I'm with you, boy. Bringing up the rear of the group is Kegan. He looks to t side and gasps in horror as he sees himself at age eighty writhing on the floor, wracked by the pain of a horrible last illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) Disease and pain, Kegan. This is your future. A PRIESTESS OF YOUTH appears. She is very young, perhaps fifteen, with the kind of beauty that makes a man catch h breath. She holds out the goblet, her face full of compassion and concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading with him) Oh please, Kegan, don't let this happen. Come to me as you were. A YOUNG KEGAN steps out beside her. He is sixteen, a gold youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to me young, Kegan. She steps forward, moving very close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Your youth is in the goblet, come to me in the rainbow. No mortal man could resist her. She holds the goblet to h lips and he drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees him and shouts) Kegan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is too late. He has drunk. The Priestess embraces Kegan. As they kiss, a rainbow arc down and envelopes them in its multi-colored light. But t colors soon fade and the rainbow becomes an arc of white light, growing brighter and more intense. In the blinding light, the Priestess begins to age, turning old before ou eyes, as does Kegan himself. The others watch, frozen in horror, as Kegan struggles to escape her embrace. But she clutches him with bony finger pressing her wrinkled mouth to his. They topple to the floor, writhing in each other's arms, their skin turning parchment. The writhing stops. Two skeletons lie on the floor, locked in fatal embrace, the white bones shimmerin in the arc of light. As the others continue through the cave, Ergo takes Titch hand and places it on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep a tight hold, boy, in case I get any more crazy ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band approaches the curving bloodstone wall of the Vortex. Great circular openings in the wall indicate the terminal of the Arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colwyn) They will hold Lyssa in the Center of the Vortex, the place of the Beast, where its power is greatest. No man can match it there. Lyssa must try to move toward us. For as we enter the Vortex and move closer ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waits, then finishes the sentence) The Beast will kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. To keep her from you. But now that we are inside the Fortress, you will be able to contact her. Colwyn kneels on the floor, elbow on knee, bending his forehead against his hand in concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa is halfway up the spiraled wall of the Vortex, midw between the Beast's hole below and the passage above - al of which are guarded by red eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must move away from the Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the passages are guarded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hand on Colwyn's shoulder) She must make a glaive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa, your bracelets. Bend them straight and cross them. Lyssa removes a pair of gold bracelets from her arm, bend them straight, and forms a cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now grip them in your hand. She wraps her fingers around the intersection of the cros converting the bracelets into a kind of homemade glaive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will your power outward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the power. Will it. As Lyssa frowns in concentration, her glaive begins to gl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colwyn) West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the western passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All directions are the same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colwyn) The spiral begins in the west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the spiral begins. Lyssa looks up to where the spiral begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move quickly. We are coming for you. We are in the Fortress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she smiles) I knew you would come. At the outer wall, the band is midway between two of the Arms. Ynyr looks from one to the other, then chooses the on the left. And in the Center, Lyssa must make a similar choice, for spiral begins midway between two of the Arms. She also chooses the one on the left. She holds the shining glaive front of her as she moves into the Arm and we hear the scrape of talons and the gutturals of frustration as the eyes are forced to retreat before it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band moves down the curving Arm, toward the Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa moves out the adjacent Arm, away from the Center. S holds her glaive in front of her, forcing back the red ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge red eyes of the Beast rise toward the top of its hole. We hear a hideous scream of rage as the Beast discovers Lyssa gone. We do not actually see it emerge from its hole, but we se the reaction of the lesser Dark Ones guarding the passage they shrink in fear, fleeing up the passages as the Beast climbs out of its hole and up the side of the spiral funn As the Beast moves into the west passage, we catch a glim of one taloned foot: it is so large that the mind can't conceive of a living creature this huge. It leaves behind trail of black mud mixed with fragments of a bizarre seaweed: dark red, with spiral leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa glances back fearfully as she hears the Beast comin up the Arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn. Where are you, Colwyn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ynyr leads the band down the Arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) We should have reached her by now. Colwyn stops, furrows his brow in concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathing hard) Come quickly, Colwyn. I can see the eyes of the Beast. Colwyn turns toward the right-hand wall of the passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyssa, touch the wall of your passage. Lyssa presses her hand against the wall behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (runs to the wall) She's on the other side of this wall. I can feel it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covers his eyes) I chose the wrong passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can see the Beast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use your sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What use is my sword? I can't reach her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to wall) Cut. Cut! Colwyn stares at him for a moment, then unsheathes his sword, grips it with both hands, and swings it at the sto wall. The blade strikes the stone with a spine-shivering clang. He swings again - another clang. But on his third swing, the blade bites into the rock, sinking to a depth several inches. On the next swing, the blade penetrates deep into the roc and on the next, it slices all the way through, tearing loose chunks of stone. Colwyn swings the sword back and forth like a scythe, cutting his way through the solid ro spraying fragments behind him. In the other passage, Lyssa presses herself against the wall, watching the Beast's eyes come closer. Suddenly, a chuck of rock bursts out of the wall near her as Colwyn c through. He seizes her arm and pulls her through the hole into the adjacent passage. Ynyr lays a hand on Colwyn's shoulder as he embraces Lyss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must move quickly. The Beast will stop at nothing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (divines his intention) You're coming with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head no) It is my fate to die in the Fortress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! You cannot know that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can. Because I choose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imperious) I forbid you! Ynyr smiles indulgently. Colwyn shrugs in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it that way. But you cannot stay. Ynyr takes Colwyn and Lyssa by the arm and moves up the passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot stay. You must both escape the Fortress or else this world is doomed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beast moves toward the hole in the passage wall. RESUME - COLWYN ET. AL. They hear the Beast tearing at the stone wall, enlarging hole to allow it to pass through. Ynyr nudges Colwyn and Lyssa up the passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go now. (turns to Torquil) Quell was wise. He knew that a man cannot ask more of his death than it help his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly, grips his hand) That is true. The wet-eyed Ergo is too choked with emotion to approach old man. Ynyr lays a hand on Titch's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Take care of Ergo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The five move up the passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly, or he will waste his life for nothing. They increase their pace. Ynyr watches them until they disappear, then backs slowly up the passage. A section of wall explodes inward as the Beast tears his through. Ynyr sees the red eyes and places a hand on his glaive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I were destined to meet, my friend. He flings his glaive, which flies to a point ten feet in front of him and hangs in midair, glowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am not so old that I can be swatted like a fly. He thrusts his hand forward - the glaive leaps toward the Beast, giving off a blinding light. The Beast roars and retreats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not so old as that, my black beauty. Now the red eyes narrow as the Beast focuses its power on the glaive. The weapon is pushed backwards, slowly but surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you will have to attack me directly to kill me. I will cost you power, my dark friend. Much power. He thrusts his hand out and the glaive leaps forward - bu only a few feet this time. The Beast's power stops it, th continues to push it back toward the old man. He holds ou his clenched fist and stops the glaive about five feet in front of him. The Beast's power is so tremendous, however that the arms of the weapon begin bending backward. Suddenly, one of the horizontal arms snaps off and flies toward Ynyr, grazing his shoulder. He staggers back, but manages to hold the glaive steady. The other horizontal a snaps off and buries itself in his chest. He goes down on one knee but continues to hold the glaive steady, though weapon is now reduced to its vertical axis. Finally, his strength gives out. He drops his arm. The vertical blade spins toward him and pierces his throat. T beast moves past his crumpled body, up the passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five make their way up the staircase to a landing. As Torquil starts up the next flight, Colwyn calls him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must find a smaller passage, where it cannot follow. They move down a corridor to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look around in confusion at the doors in each of the twelve sides of the huge room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the Fortress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Arctic ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to door) That way. I can feel the cold. They move to the door, which opens onto a long stairway leading up. At the top, we can see snow blowing past the opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing up) She's right. Look. They hear the Beast coming closer and start up the long stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the five make their way upward, a terrible noise from below makes them stop and look back: the Beast is tearing away the rock, enlarging the passage to follow them. They quicken their pace. Along the stairs are small piles of fine powder: the mort between the stones is crumbling and trickling down the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five emerge from the staircase and make their way acr the Arctic landscape, toward the outer wall. Colwyn looks back and sees the Beast tearing its way out of the Fortre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make for the wall. I'll catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colwyn, don't be a fool. You can't do battle with that thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way to outrun it. You know that. This is what Ynyr was preparing me for. It's what he died for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll tap him on the head with my sword hilt if I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, but with iron authority) You'll lead the others to the wall as I tell you. Now. Torquil bows to Colwyn's authority; he leads the others toward the wall. Colwyn pulls off his hauberk, useless in this battle, and faces the Beast in his tunic. The wind whips the thin cloth as he advances across the ice to whe the Beast waits, obscured by the thickly falling snow. Suddenly, a gigantic chunk of ice flies straight at him. raises his hand and the ice shatters, streaking past him harmlessly. Now he begins to concentrate, focusing his power until hi body gleams - then shimmers - then bursts into flame with tongues of white fire leaping from his body as if it had been doused in gasoline. The flame is under his power; it doesn't harm him, nor does it melt the snow he walks on. only harms when he wills it - as when he sees a patch of Dark Ones approaching from the side. He sweeps his arm toward them and an arc of flames rolls across the ice lik wave, washing over them and leaving their charred bodies writhing in the snow. The Beast is moving back and forth in an area of ice ridg and hummocks, dimly visible through the heavy snowfall. N it is a stone tower, some fifty feet high. The tower is suddenly lifted from the ground and hurled at Colwyn. He makes a downward chop with his hand and the tower splits the middle, the two pieces flying past on either side of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am no feeble old man for you to crush with two blows. (moves forward, grim-faced) This is for that old man. He sweeps his arm toward the Beast and an arc of flame ro across the ice. As the Beast sidesteps, the flaming arc slices off the top of an ice hummock, leaving the flat surface boiling and steaming from the heat. Colwyn presses forward, driven by grief and rage. He launches a second arc of flame, one end of which catches Beast's side. The Beast roars with pain and retreats, dri back by Colwyn's power. He launches a third arc, and this one strikes the Beast's head, staggering it. The Beast is wounded now: one of its huge eyes is swollen half shut, the skin around it badly charred. Enraged, the Beast counterattacks. Huge projectiles streak toward Colw first come blocks of ice, then great fragments of stone. Finally, the stone fragments begin to burn, screaming through the air like meteors. The projectiles shatter against Colwyn's protective shiel of flame, but the force of repeated impact drives him backward. Small fragments of ice and stone actually pierc the shield, tearing his tunic, cutting his skin. He is bleeding from several flesh wounds and his forehead is burned by a fragment of flaming rock. But the Beast's power is not infinite. The hail of projectiles slows, then stops. Colwyn resumes his advance He chops his arm downward: we hear a sharp crack and an i hummock EXPLODES near the Beast. He chops again and an ic ridge EXPLODES, leaving a deep crack in the ice. The Beas hurls another projectile, but Colwyn brushes it aside as it were a mosquito and sweeps an arc of flame at the Beas to back it off. Then he resumes chopping with his arm: crack followed closely on crack as the ice around the Beast is sliced an shattered by Colwyn's power. The section of ice on which Beast stands suddenly drops a foot or so. The Beast hurls final projectile, then Colwyn cracks the ice again. We he a deep RUMBLE and a huge section of ice collapses, fallin into the depths of the Fortress, carrying the Beast with Watching from a distance, Torquil sees the exhausted Colw staggering on the ice, barely able to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) I'll get him. Make for the wall. Torquil heads for Colwyn. Ergo pushes Lyssa and Titch tow the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly, quickly to the wall. But Ergo himself turns around and follows Torquil to wher Colwyn is stumbling on the ice. Dark Ones flit between th ice hummocks, converging on them. As Torquil helps Colwyn toward the wall, Ergo forms a rea guard, armed with butcher knives from his voluminous coat As Dark Ones lunge out of the swirling snow, the little m faces them fearlessly, hurling his knives with deadly aim protect his friends: one creature falls with a knife betw the eyes, another with a knife in the neck, a third pierc through the heart. They reach the parapet, where Torquil and Lyssa help Colw over the wall. The five clamber down the face of the wall and Torquil is about to jump off onto the icy ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to horizon) Wait! The two suns are about to come up. They remain on the wal except for Ergo, who slips on a sheet of ice and slides toward the ground. Titch reaches out and grabs his hand, holding him on the wall, though Ergo's legs are buried in snow up to the knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clinging to the wall, the five look out on a green valley Ergo's legs are still buried to the knees, but in the ground. The stones of the wall are shifting. The Fortress collapsing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumps to the ground) Away from the wall! Torquil and Colwyn haul Ergo out of the ground and move a from the wall. They watch the Fortress crumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a fitting monument for Ynyr and Quell and the others. The Fortress sinks from sight, leaving a green valley in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a better one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They make their way across the glen, Colwyn and Lyssa wit arms around each other, Titch riding on Torquil's shoulde and the Ergo-puppy riding on Titch's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around) Where's Ergo? Titch hands her the Ergo-puppy, who licks her face. She laughs and sets the puppy down. It runs in front of them, frisking. PEASANT FAMILIES come out of the forest and join them. Children chase the puppy through the grass. FADE OUT.
